title: Bot Bans Incoming
body:
Hey everyone,

Last week, we banned accounts found to be cheating.  This week, we're banning botted accounts.  We want each and every game to feel competitive, and having bots on your team cripples your ability to work together as a team toward victory.  As a result of these bans, we expect players will encounter fewer bots in their games, but there's still more we can do in our efforts against bots.

We wish we could provide more context, but we won't be answering questions about how we detect bots to avoid being reverse engineered. Just know that we're committed to keeping these bots down.  We'll continue to improve detection as bots try to get around it, and we're working toward other solutions that will decrease motivations for botting.

replies.body:
Thanks for the hard work.

Any chance you guys can add an option to the report feature for people that we suspect are cheating or botting so we can weed them out faster for you?

Getting community support to identify bots can be helpful for investigations, and I'm excited to hear you want to help.  We've thought about this feature, but aren't sure if we want to add it yet.  One reason is that  we can't simply ban bots off of reports alone...we need to be able to identify and ignore false reports.

For now, I'd suggest using an existing category that most closely matches the bot's activity (usually players use 'Intentional Feeding' or "Refused to Communicate with Team').  In the report comments, tell us that you're reporting a suspected bot and describe the activity that tipped you off.

What I would really like to see is a report button that you can use in champion select, or perhaps one that you can do from your 'recent players' tab, as sometimes you can't get into the post-game screen to report someone from your previous game.

I might be a newbie but what does a bot do to cheat?

Bots don't necessarily cheat.  The likely scenario is that "bot" summoners, who are actually AIs (who act/play similar to the bots in Co-op vs AI), join PvP queues.  The result is that the team with the bot(s) typically loses because bots are only given specific commands (e.g. recall when health is below 30%) and are not as adaptable to situations as humans are.  This is done because bots can (slowly but surely) grind to level 30 without any human effort, hence why it may be called "cheating."  Other bot accounts add random players and advertise URLs toward viruses or products.  Either way, bots are nuisances to how enjoyable our games are, therefore they are getting banned.

We hear that players want secondary accounts.  As for the reasons why, we're sympathetic to some (e.g. "I want to play with my friends who just signed up"), but not others (e.g. "I want to stomp noobs").  We're not sure that selling level 30 accounts is the best solution.  There may be other ways we can support the 'good' use cases for smurfing in a way that doesn't require creating a secondary account.

I think a problem with the game at the moment is that it is not a single-grind game. By that, I mean that when you first start playing the game, you start playing just to get frustrated at it, toss something at the screen, and then curse the heavens for a few weeks before you get bored of the next game or a friend calls you back, and you give it another shot. Before inevitably quitting again.

I feel that levels off heavily after level 30 because of the even games, though not always by skill. I don't think that's a bad thing.

Thing is, unlike most genres of games, MOBAs in general might best represent a board game. Extremely confined playing field, very similar play of objects on both sides, a start and an end that gets repetitive between games, and strategy to progress through the game.

__________________________________________________

Now let's compare to one such popular board game, Monopoly.

LoL lets you pick the strategy you want to play. You can play the support, akin to the purples or light-blues, a good early build to get moving, in an attempt to squander the higher roles before they can get their full footing, but not likely to win the game alone. You can play the bruiser, akin to the light purples and oranges, who tend to need a burst of early game effort to ensure the endgame goes their way. You can play the tank, akin to the reds and the yellows, and sacrifice a heavy amount of health (often relying on support disruption) to shut down any real counterplay late game. And then there's the greens and blues... those darned carries that need help from just about everyone it seems... But they manage this much power, and you better start teaming up against that fella. Immunities galore amongst other teammates to ensure that carry goes down before dangerous.

And then there's assassins. They want to be everywhere at all times, and poke for heavy damage early with **NO MONEY WHATSOEVER**, but (should) fall off heavily late. Clearly, they must be the railroads/utilities.

__________________________________________________

So, I can pay you money to ensure that I get the doggy as my character (Warwick). But not just the doggy. I want that doggy that ate that manatee, because that looks cooler on the board. However, I am playing this game, and people are starting off with full sets of light purples and oranges, and new people aren't able to afford it yet. How can you make fun games for people when leveling up often occurs with not only better Monopoly strategizers, they also start with properties initially. It's not fun. I have also gotten a taste of the 1-30 climb again after I made it the first time (legitimately), and it's a challenge as a veteran player, on several levels. But, one of the easiest leveling tools to fix, the easiest to remedy the situation, should have been simply to make the board even on all sides, though they *may* not be able to afford all the fix-ins for every strat possible... they should at least feel that their strat has a fighter's chance of pulling out a victory in the end.

So, c'mon, banker. I'm tired of you handing over properties during pre-game just because they have played a meager amount more than me. I want an even playing field. I want my *low-leveled friends* to have an even playing field, as it's not so fun to see them torn to shreds by a slightly unfortunate roll of the dice. A lost game should feel like *I played wrong*. I shouldn't feel like the board was set up against me, especially as a new player.

I don't want to say that new players are fully ready to rock the League at playtime of a level 10 player. But at least have them play the same game as we are so that they can actually practice it. For some reason, they're playing goalie in a WAY bigger net. And yes, I can do what I just did, because League is clearly also a sport.

The "good" use cases could be accommodated by new features designed to address what the players actually want to do.  For example, some type of mentor system to allow level 30 players to help introduce new players to the game without forcing them to create another account.

I can't really think of many other honestly legitimate reasons.

 - A second account to play while the main account has queue-dodged - legitimate, but only because of problems in champion select, Ranked Team Builder should make this much less necessary
 - A second account to play while the first account is banned - not legitimate
 - A second account to play against lower-levelled / lower-ranked players - not legitimate
 - A second account to level up to plat/diamond/challenger/whatever again - not really legitimate, every game you play in ranked is disrupting the normal outcome of that game for the other 9 players (if your skill level is really that different from where you are placed)
 - A second account to practice champions and not lose too much ranking - somewhat legitimate, though a Ranked Team Builder that slightly adjusts you MMR based on champion familiarity would help here

* - Tournament only Account (ESL/ESEA what not)
* - Trying out new Stuff in General
